div.p:
Dearest Mother; Here we are again with
this kind friend Lady Elizabeth W. who met us with open arms & open heart at
met us with open arms & open heart at
the head of the stairs when we returned
and made us feel immediately at home
again in her house and as if we had ne-
ver never separated from her. Every thing in our
rooms prepared in perfect comfort for
us. The low arm chair at the fire - the foot
stool - the writing table turned to the right
way for the light for me - Oh my dear mo-
ther mother politeness in the manner of doing
kindness, as you and Aunt Ruxton so
well know adds incalculably to the
value of the favors conferred.

Fanny who is scribbling to you
says she has told you what a dreary drive
we had from Deep Dene to Kensington &
how completely we were prevented from
enjoying the sight of Richmond by rain &
fog. I came round by Richmond on
purpose because my aunt R was so
fond of it and I wanted to see & to shew it to
my companions. Fanny had seen it &
(had her own recollections! -) But we have
had so few little disappointments of this
sort during our journies that we have no right
to complain

Fan has told you of Mr. & Mrs. Waldegrave
& all we have heard from them - So
I have written to Lord Grey to ask
when & where I may present little
Francis to him

Dr. Holland dines here tomorrow
and you shall hear immediately what he
says of Fanny. But I know all he can say
is that he is proud to see her looking so well
- Mr. S Whitbread asked yesterday evening
whether I would trust him to ride with her
- He had heard me say when I was here
before that riding was good for her & that
I wished she could ride. He had a nice little
poney which Jack said is as safe and which
he was sure she wd. like - Fanny & I accepted
this kind offer and she has had a delightful
ride in the park with Jack riding behind
them - After Jack had gone a few yards
he said he must turn back he bethought him
thus the silk hand
. he had tied round his
neck was not smart enough or as he said
respectful enough for riding with a lady
so back he went to equip himself more
to his notions of propriety

Good natured Miss Grant ( of the dear
Aunt Mary kind) came out with me &
& walked without her bonnet & with
one end of her shawl round her & the other
end round myself up the Kensington road
to the park for the pleasure of seeing them
trit-a-trot till they were quite out of sight
